Title:
Phylogenetic relationships within Lachnaceae (Ascomycota):
Laevipulum, Erioscyphella, and species within Capitotricha bicolor
Abstract:
The saprotrophic genus Capitotricha (Raitv.) Baral
(Lachnaceae, Helotiales) primarily includes xerotolerant species
characterized by apothecia with long, mostly white, thick-walled hairs
tipped with apical crystals, ectal excipulum of thick-walled textura
prismatica, and the presence of yellow to orange lipid bodies in
hymenial elements (Baral and Matočec, 2005). There are 9 species known
worldwide, although their phylogenetic context and interrelatedness
remain poorly understood. Within the genus there are several
morphologically distinct species (Lachnum patulum (Pers.: Fr.) Rehm ss.
Fuckel, Capitotricha scabrovillosa (W. Phillips) Baral, comb. ined., C.
crystalligera (Sacc.) Järv & Baral, comb. ined., and three new
species reported by Baral and Matočec (2005), as well as a group of
species with similar overall morphological characters (Capitotricha
bicolor (Bull.: Fr.) Baral, C. fagiseda Baral nom. prov., and C. rubi
(Bres.) Baral). Among these three species, Capitotricha rubi differs
from the other two by its smaller asci and ascospores, and it was for a
long time treated as a variety of C. bicolor. It was elevated to species
level by Baral (in Baral and Krieglsteiner 1985), who at the same time
proposed that two lineages could be distinguished in Capitotricha
bicolor on the basis of ascospore measurements  one growing on twigs and
cupules of Fagus (C. fagiseda), and the other one on twigs of other
hosts (C. bicolor s.str.). Suková (2005) noted as additional characters
the differences in thickness of the excipulum and the relative abundance
of apical crystals. All these characters are overlapping, however, and
there is a clear need for a better understanding of species delimitation
in this group, especially among the species inhabiting woody
substrates.
